[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Samurai](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/Samurai "wikipedia:Special:Search/Samurai")***

- '*Sam' redirects here. For the guardian of the [black market](/wiki/Black_market "Black market"), see [One-eyed Sam](/wiki/One-eyed_Sam "One-eyed Sam").*

**Samurai** are Japanese warriors who adhere to the discipline of [bushido](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/bushido "wikipedia:bushido") (honor) and fight their enemies using ancient martial arts. Therefore they start out [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") and [human](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)"), but can be of either gender. Their first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice#Gifts "Sacrifice") is [Snickersnee](/wiki/Snickersnee "Snickersnee").

The Samurai is one of the [strongest roles](/wiki/Role_difficulty "Role difficulty") in the early game, and thus an excellent choice for a new player. The [guidebook](/wiki/Guidebook "Guidebook") describes them like this:

```
              Samurai are the elite warriors of feudal Nippon.   They  are
         lightly  armored  and  quick, and wear the dai-sho, two swords of
         the deadliest keenness.
```

## Starting equipment

Each samurai starts with the following:[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

- a +0 [katana](/wiki/Katana "Katana") (samurai sword)
- a +0 [wakizashi](/wiki/Wakizashi "Wakizashi") (short sword)
- a +0 [yumi](/wiki/Yumi "Yumi") (bow)
- 26 to 45 [ya](/wiki/Ya "Ya") (bamboo arrows)
- a +0 [rustproof](/wiki/Rustproof "Rustproof") [splint mail](/wiki/Splint_mail "Splint mail")
- a [blindfold](/wiki/Blindfold "Blindfold") (20% chance)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

Instead of a random pet, a samurai always starts with a little dog called Hachi. This is in reference to *[Hachikō](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hachik%C5%8D "wikipedia:Hachikō")*, a famous Japanese dog who faithfully waited for the return of his dead owner for nine years until his own death. *Hachi* means eight, in reference of his birth order in the litter, and *ko* implies affection.

## Special rules

Samurai get a +1 bonus to [multishot](/wiki/Multishot "Multishot") when firing ya from a yumi.

Samurai may perform a [shattering blow](/wiki/Shattering_blow "Shattering blow") while wielding a katana; other roles must wield a two-handed weapon to perform one.

### Code of Conduct

The bushido code requires that samurai behave honorably. Dishonorable acts will incur an [alignment penalty](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record") and display a guilt message. Examples include:

- [Digging](/wiki/Dig "Dig") up a [grave](/wiki/Grave "Grave"): −1 *"You disturb the honorable dead!"*
- Attacking a [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") or [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame") creature: −1 *"You dishonorably attack the innocent!"*
- Attacking with a [poisoned](/wiki/Poison "Poison") weapon: −1 *"You dishonorably use a poisoned weapon!"*

A Samurai with a non-Lawful alignment (probably from wearing a [helm of opposite alignment](/wiki/Helm_of_opposite_alignment "Helm of opposite alignment")) will still receive the message, but will not suffer the alignment penalty.

## Strategy

### Early game

#### Weapons

While it may be tempting to start [two-weapon combat](/wiki/Two-weapon_combat "Two-weapon combat") with your starting katana and wakizashi, the [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") penalty is quite severe, the [wakizashi](/wiki/Wakizashi "Wakizashi") is a middling weapon that uses a different weapon skill from your katana, and you won't train your base weapon skill while twoweaponing. It's better to use your katana alone, and wait until you've found another long sword later.

As far as weapons go, the samurai should not bother with any sword other than a [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword"). The katana they start with is the finest one-handed non-artifact weapon in the game. Since the samurai can reach expert level in [two-weapon combat](/wiki/Two-weapon_combat "Two-weapon combat") they are better off swinging two [long swords](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword")/katana than one of any larger non-artifact weapon. However, in the early game it is important to build up skill in individual weapons, which cannot be done while using two weapons.

Of course, the samurai becomes even more powerful *with* an artifact weapon. Early options include [Snickersnee](/wiki/Snickersnee "Snickersnee"), a buffed-up katana that's your guaranteed first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift"), or [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur"), an artifact weapon that has a 1⁄6 chance of being created if you dip a long sword into a [fountain](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain"). You may do this when you have attained [experience level](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") 5, though you may also wish to delay doing so until you have better HP or equipment to handle the possible fountain monsters. Note that you must use an actual long sword to accomplish this, do *not* dip your starting katana into a fountain to try to accomplish this. Once you have a decent artifact weapon and expert skill in long sword, slide your original katana over to the secondary hand in two-weapon combat, and it will continue to add its damage to your attacks.

The yumi is a good long distance ranged weapon, especially given your multishot bonus with ya. It will aid you in situations where melee combat may prove fatal—fighting [floating eyes](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye") and [cockatrices](/wiki/Cockatrice "Cockatrice") for example. Since you're likely to want to switch to shuriken once you retrieve some from your Quest, consider not advancing bow skill to Expert to save three skill slots.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit e8212743](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/e8212743825365569b2162384eb653520b59c1d3), non-[Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") have a 1⁄30 chance of transforming a long sword into [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") by dipping, making [Snickersnee](/wiki/Snickersnee "Snickersnee") more of a priority in the early game unless they find an [altar](/wiki/Altar "Altar") and a means of securing high [luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck").

#### General

The samurai strategy is very simple: If it moves, stab it, and if it's [sessile](/wiki/Sessile "Sessile"), stab it anyway. Samurai are also good ranged warriors, receiving a bonus to hit and damage when shooting ya from a yumi. Samurai aren't good at [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting"), but are very unlikely to need it; the katana and splint mail they start with also make the first few levels a breeze.

### Mid game

#### Objectives

The Samurai quest item is the [Tsurugi of Muramasa](/wiki/Tsurugi_of_Muramasa "Tsurugi of Muramasa"), a powerful two-handed tsurugi with the ability to bisect enemies (i. e. kill them outright) 5% of the time, much like the [Vorpal Blade](/wiki/Vorpal_Blade "Vorpal Blade"). Therefore it is not a good idea to engage your quest nemesis in honourable melee combat, since he might bisect you; making things worse, he ignores [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth"). It's better to zap him with a wand of death. If you don't have one, other techniques include zapping him with a wand of sleep or hurling a potion of paralysis at him before attacking so that he can't fight back, protecting yourself with a [scroll of earth](/wiki/Scroll_of_earth "Scroll of earth") on the upstair and killing him with ranged attacks, [polymorphing](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a [black dragon](/wiki/Black_dragon "Black dragon") and disintegrating him, and so forth. If you have a strong melee attack, you could just wear an [amulet of life saving](/wiki/Amulet_of_life_saving "Amulet of life saving") and hope for the best, possibly retreating if you have to burn the amulet; actually, having an [amulet of life saving](/wiki/Amulet_of_life_saving "Amulet of life saving") is probably a good idea anyway no matter what strategy you choose, just in case.

The quest is notable for producing a lot of loot, especially attack wands, which your opponents will use against you. [Reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection"), or at least resistance to sleep, fire, and cold, are highly desirable.

#### Weapons

With maxed strength and enchantment, shuriken and ya deal roughly comparable damage (since ya do not benefit from your [strength bonus](/wiki/Strength "Strength")). Ya are slightly more effective when you have a substantial [damage bonus](/wiki/Ring_of_increase_damage "Ring of increase damage"), thanks to the Samurai's +1 multishot bonus when using them. Shuriken, on the other hand, do not require a wielded launcher (potentially saving valuable turns), and are generally more plentiful thanks to the [Quest](/wiki/Samurai_quest "Samurai quest"). Since you take an [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record") penalty when using poisoned missiles, poisoning your entire stack is a [Bad Idea](/wiki/Bad_Idea "Bad Idea"), but it might be worth poisoning a subset of your missiles to use against monsters such as [minotaurs](/wiki/Minotaur "Minotaur") and [mind flayers](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer"), where killing them quickly is more important than a few points of alignment.

The [Tsurugi of Muramasa](/wiki/Tsurugi_of_Muramasa "Tsurugi of Muramasa") isn't as useful as it might seem, as it compares unfavorably to twoweaponing Excalibur and your starting katana, and doesn't provide any essential [extrinsics](/wiki/Extrinsics "Extrinsics").

### Late game

#### Weapons

Samurai typically get the most out of two-weaponing, using Excalibur with an offhand katana or silver saber through the endgame; [Frost Brand](/wiki/Frost_Brand "Frost Brand"), [Fire Brand](/wiki/Fire_Brand "Fire Brand") or [Grayswandir](/wiki/Grayswandir "Grayswandir") can replace Excalibur in the primary slot if you have them available, and can also be swapped into that slot against specific monsters. If no other source of reflection is available for you, you can forgo two-weapon fighting for a [shield of reflection](/wiki/Shield_of_reflection "Shield of reflection").

#### General

If you want to twoweapon in the late game and also wear an [amulet of life saving](/wiki/Amulet_of_life_saving "Amulet of life saving"), you will probably want a [cloak of magic resistance](/wiki/Cloak_of_magic_resistance "Cloak of magic resistance") paired with [silver dragon scale mail](/wiki/Silver_dragon_scale_mail "Silver dragon scale mail"), using a wish for the cloak if necessary. Relying on a quest artifact like the [Magic Mirror of Merlin](/wiki/Magic_Mirror_of_Merlin "Magic Mirror of Merlin") for magic resistance is risky, because the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") can steal it, leaving you vulnerable to his [touch of death](/wiki/Touch_of_death "Touch of death").

### SLASH'EM

Samurai can be played more or less the same way in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") as in Vanilla. Just be a little more wary of enemies' stronger attack power, using your ya and scribbling the E word whenever enemies are near.

- Their "kiii" [technique](/wiki/Technique "Technique") gives a temporary boost to your attack power. Due to the Samurai's strong attack power you may never use it, but it can be useful if you're facing somewhat powerful enemies and want to take them out quickly.

- SLASH'EM allows you to #twoweapon two artifacts at the same time. Considering that Samurai can easily get both [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") and [Snickersnee](/wiki/Snickersnee "Snickersnee")—two of the most powerful weapons in the game—and are able to advance both longsword and #twoweapon to expert, this is a huge advantage.

- Since a Samurai wielding both Excalibur and Snickersnee will do large amounts of damage even with zero enchantment, enchanting your weapons is a low priority. If you find any scrolls of enchant weapon, consider blessing it and enchanting your [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn")—enchanting unicorn horns increases their chances of working in SLASH'EM.

- Once you have at least a [submachine gun](/wiki/Submachine_gun "Submachine gun") and a bunch of bullets, don't bother any more with the yumi. Firearms are superior to bows and arrows. Later, replace your submachine gun with an [assault rifle](/wiki/Assault_rifle "Assault rifle"). The assault rifle will be very good for the special cases where melee is a bad idea.

- Save up gold for shops, or get good at stealing: along with rogues and barbarians, samurai are massively overcharged in shops, paying twice as much. This is mainly relevant when you find a [magic lamp](/wiki/Magic_lamp "Magic lamp") in a shop, which in SLASH'EM has a base price of 1000zm.

- A good [ascension kit](/wiki/Ascension_kit "Ascension kit") for a Samurai is:

  - +7 [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") two-weaponed with +7 [Snickersnee](/wiki/Snickersnee "Snickersnee") or other powerful artifact weapon
  - an [amulet of life saving](/wiki/Amulet_of_life_saving "Amulet of life saving") or [amulet of flying](/wiki/Amulet_of_flying "Amulet of flying")
  - +5 [silver dragon scale mail](/wiki/Silver_dragon_scale_mail "Silver dragon scale mail")
  - +7 [cloak of magic resistance](/wiki/Cloak_of_magic_resistance "Cloak of magic resistance") (enchant an [elven cloak](/wiki/Elven_cloak "Elven cloak") to +7 and [upgrade](/wiki/Upgrading_objects "Upgrading objects") it)
  - +5 [gauntlets of power](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_power "Gauntlets of power") or [gauntlets of dexterity](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_dexterity "Gauntlets of dexterity")
  - +5 fireproof [speed boots](/wiki/Speed_boots "Speed boots") for the extra attacks, [jumping boots](/wiki/Jumping_boots "Jumping boots") for the extra movement, [water walking boots](/wiki/Water_walking_boots "Water walking boots") to be safe from [create pool](/wiki/Create_pool "Create pool"), or +7 [elven boots](/wiki/Elven_boots "Elven boots") for the extra AC and stealth
  - +5 [shirt](/wiki/Shirt "Shirt")
  - greased +5 [helm of telepathy](/wiki/Helm_of_telepathy "Helm of telepathy") or +7 [elven leather helm](/wiki/Elven_leather_helm "Elven leather helm")
  - A +7 [assault rifle](/wiki/Assault_rifle "Assault rifle") and bullets
  - All the other standard ascension kit items that all roles need (bag, rings, potions, wands, tools, etc.)

Samurai
'Sam' redirects here. For the guardian of the black market, see One-eyed Sam.

Samurai are Japanese warriors who adhere to the discipline of bushido (honor) and fight their enemies using ancient martial arts. Therefore they start out lawful and human, but can be of either gender. Their first sacrifice gift is Snickersnee.

The Samurai is one of the strongest roles in the early game, and thus an excellent choice for a new player. The guidebook describes them like this: 

              Samurai are the elite warriors of feudal Nippon.   They  are
         lightly  armored  and  quick, and wear the dai-sho, two swords of
         the deadliest keenness.

Starting equipment

Each samurai starts with the following:[1][2]

  • a +0 katana (samurai sword)
  • a +0 wakizashi (short sword)
  • a +0 yumi (bow)
  • 26 to 45 ya (bamboo arrows)
  • a +0 rustproof splint mail
  • a blindfold (20% chance)[3]

Instead of a random pet, a samurai always starts with a little dog called Hachi. This is in reference to Hachikō, a famous Japanese dog who faithfully waited for the return of his dead owner for nine years until his own death. Hachi means eight, in reference of his birth order in the litter, and ko implies affection.

Intrinsics

Samurai gain intrinsics at these experience levels:[4]

  • Level 1: speed
  • Level 15: stealth

Skills

Special rules

Samurai get a +1 bonus to multishot when firing ya from a yumi.

Samurai may perform a shattering blow while wielding a katana; other roles must wield a two-handed weapon to perform one.

Japanese names for items

Since the samurai are Japanese, some of the game items use Japanese names in place of their regular English names when playing as a Samurai. The following is a list of those items with their Japanese names:

English Japanese

There are also some regular items that are uniquely Japanese. Once identified, these are described using their Japanese name, regardless of which role you are playing. These items are the following:

  • ya ("bamboo arrow")
  • yumi ("long bow")
  • katana ("samurai sword")
  • tsurugi ("long samurai sword")
  • shuriken ("throwing star")

Additionally some pieces of dialog are also changed. On losing a level or dying, you receive the message "Sayonara", instead of the usual "Goodbye"; when starting or loading a game, it greets you with "Konichi wa"; and friendly shopkeepers and priests greet you with "Irasshaimase".

Code of Conduct

The bushido code requires that samurai behave honorably. Dishonorable acts will incur an alignment penalty and display a guilt message. Examples include:

  • Digging up a grave: −1 "You disturb the honorable dead!"
  • Attacking a peaceful or tame creature: −1 "You dishonorably attack the innocent!"
  • Attacking with a poisoned weapon: −1 "You dishonorably use a poisoned weapon!"

A Samurai with a non-Lawful alignment (probably from wearing a helm of opposite alignment) will still receive the message, but will not suffer the alignment penalty.

Strategy

Early game

Weapons

While it may be tempting to start two-weapon combat with your starting katana and wakizashi, the to-hit penalty is quite severe, the wakizashi is a middling weapon that uses a different weapon skill from your katana, and you won't train your base weapon skill while twoweaponing. It's better to use your katana alone, and wait until you've found another long sword later.

As far as weapons go, the samurai should not bother with any sword other than a long sword. The katana they start with is the finest one-handed non-artifact weapon in the game. Since the samurai can reach expert level in two-weapon combat they are better off swinging two long swords/katana than one of any larger non-artifact weapon. However, in the early game it is important to build up skill in individual weapons, which cannot be done while using two weapons.

Of course, the samurai becomes even more powerful with an artifact weapon. Early options include Snickersnee, a buffed-up katana that's your guaranteed first sacrifice gift, or Excalibur, an artifact weapon that has a 1⁄6 chance of being created if you dip a long sword into a fountain. You may do this when you have attained experience level 5, though you may also wish to delay doing so until you have better HP or equipment to handle the possible fountain monsters. Note that you must use an actual long sword to accomplish this, do not dip your starting katana into a fountain to try to accomplish this. Once you have a decent artifact weapon and expert skill in long sword, slide your original katana over to the secondary hand in two-weapon combat, and it will continue to add its damage to your attacks.

The yumi is a good long distance ranged weapon, especially given your multishot bonus with ya. It will aid you in situations where melee combat may prove fatal—fighting floating eyes and cockatrices for example. Since you're likely to want to switch to shuriken once you retrieve some from your Quest, consider not advancing bow skill to Expert to save three skill slots.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Per commit e8212743, non-Knights have a 1⁄30 chance of transforming a long sword into Excalibur by dipping, making Snickersnee more of a priority in the early game unless they find an altar and a means of securing high luck.

General

The samurai strategy is very simple: If it moves, stab it, and if it's sessile, stab it anyway. Samurai are also good ranged warriors, receiving a bonus to hit and damage when shooting ya from a yumi. Samurai aren't good at spellcasting, but are very unlikely to need it; the katana and splint mail they start with also make the first few levels a breeze.

Mid game

Objectives

The Samurai quest item is the Tsurugi of Muramasa, a powerful two-handed tsurugi with the ability to bisect enemies (i. e. kill them outright) 5% of the time, much like the Vorpal Blade. Therefore it is not a good idea to engage your quest nemesis in honourable melee combat, since he might bisect you; making things worse, he ignores Elbereth. It's better to zap him with a wand of death. If you don't have one, other techniques include zapping him with a wand of sleep or hurling a potion of paralysis at him before attacking so that he can't fight back, protecting yourself with a scroll of earth on the upstair and killing him with ranged attacks, polymorphing into a black dragon and disintegrating him, and so forth. If you have a strong melee attack, you could just wear an amulet of life saving and hope for the best, possibly retreating if you have to burn the amulet; actually, having an amulet of life saving is probably a good idea anyway no matter what strategy you choose, just in case.

The quest is notable for producing a lot of loot, especially attack wands, which your opponents will use against you. Reflection, or at least resistance to sleep, fire, and cold, are highly desirable.

Weapons

With maxed strength and enchantment, shuriken and ya deal roughly comparable damage (since ya do not benefit from your strength bonus). Ya are slightly more effective when you have a substantial damage bonus, thanks to the Samurai's +1 multishot bonus when using them. Shuriken, on the other hand, do not require a wielded launcher (potentially saving valuable turns), and are generally more plentiful thanks to the Quest. Since you take an alignment record penalty when using poisoned missiles, poisoning your entire stack is a Bad Idea, but it might be worth poisoning a subset of your missiles to use against monsters such as minotaurs and mind flayers, where killing them quickly is more important than a few points of alignment.

The Tsurugi of Muramasa isn't as useful as it might seem, as it compares unfavorably to twoweaponing Excalibur and your starting katana, and doesn't provide any essential extrinsics.

Late game

Weapons

Samurai typically get the most out of two-weaponing, using Excalibur with an offhand katana or silver saber through the endgame; Frost Brand, Fire Brand or Grayswandir can replace Excalibur in the primary slot if you have them available, and can also be swapped into that slot against specific monsters. If no other source of reflection is available for you, you can forgo two-weapon fighting for a shield of reflection.

General

If you want to twoweapon in the late game and also wear an amulet of life saving, you will probably want a cloak of magic resistance paired with silver dragon scale mail, using a wish for the cloak if necessary. Relying on a quest artifact like the Magic Mirror of Merlin for magic resistance is risky, because the Wizard of Yendor can steal it, leaving you vulnerable to his touch of death.

Rank titles

The status line shows you to be one of the following ranks when you reach the specified experience level:

  • XL 1-2: Hatamoto
  • XL 3-5: Ronin
  • XL 6-9: Ninja/Kunoichi
  • XL 10-13: Joshu
  • XL 14-17: Ryoshu
  • XL 18-21: Kokushu
  • XL 22-25: Daimyo
  • XL 26-29: Kuge
  • XL 30: Shogun

Quest

Main article: Samurai quest

The Samurai quest sees you fight Ashikaga Takauji for the Tsurugi of Muramasa.

  • Their "kiii" technique gives a temporary boost to your attack power. Due to the Samurai's strong attack power you may never use it, but it can be useful if you're facing somewhat powerful enemies and want to take them out quickly.
  • SLASH'EM allows you to #twoweapon two artifacts at the same time. Considering that Samurai can easily get both Excalibur and Snickersnee—two of the most powerful weapons in the game—and are able to advance both longsword and #twoweapon to expert, this is a huge advantage.
  • Since a Samurai wielding both Excalibur and Snickersnee will do large amounts of damage even with zero enchantment, enchanting your weapons is a low priority.   • Once you have at least a submachine gun and a bunch of bullets, don't bother any more with the yumi. Firearms are superior to bows and arrows. Later, replace your submachine gun with an assault rifle. The assault rifle will be very good for the special cases where melee is a bad idea.

    • +5 fireproof speed boots for the extra attacks, jumping boots for the extra movement, water walking boots to be safe from create pool, or +7 elven boots for the extra AC and stealth
    • +5 shirt
    • greased +5 helm of telepathy or +7 elven leather helm
    • A +7 assault rifle and bullets
    • All the other standard ascension kit items that all roles need (bag, rings, potions, wands, tools, etc.)

A Samurai with a non-Lawful alignment (probably from wearing a [[helm of opposite alignment]]) will still receive the message, but will not suffer the alignment penalty. == Strategy == === Early game === ==== Weapons ==== While it may be tempting to start [[two-weapon combat]] with your starting katana and wakizashi, the [[to-hit]] penalty is quite severe, the [[wakizashi]] is a middling weapon that uses a different weapon skill from your katana, and you won't train your base weapon skill while twoweaponing. It's better to use your katana alone, and wait until you've found another long sword later. As far as weapons go, the samurai should not bother with any sword other than a [[long sword]]. The katana they start with is the finest one-handed non-artifact weapon in the game. Since the samurai can reach expert level in [[two-weapon combat]] they are better off swinging two [[long sword]]s/katana than one of any larger non-artifact weapon. However, in the early game it is important to build up skill in individual weapons, which cannot be done while using two weapons. Of course, the samurai becomes even more powerful ''with'' an artifact weapon. Early options include [[Snickersnee]], a buffed-up katana that's your guaranteed first [[sacrifice gift]], or [[Excalibur]], an artifact weapon that has a {{frac|6}} chance of being created if you dip a long sword into a [[fountain]]. You may do this when you have attained [[experience level]] 5, though you may also wish to delay doing so until you have better HP or equipment to handle the possible fountain monsters. Note that you must use an actual long sword to accomplish this, do ''not'' dip your starting katana into a fountain to try to accomplish this. Once you have a decent artifact weapon and expert skill in long sword, slide your original katana over to the secondary hand in two-weapon combat, and it will continue to add its damage to your attacks. The yumi is a good long distance ranged weapon, especially given your multishot bonus with ya. It will aid you in situations where melee combat may prove fatal—fighting [[floating eye]]s and [[cockatrice]]s for example. Since you're likely to want to switch to shuriken once you retrieve some from your Quest, consider not advancing bow skill to Expert to save three skill slots. {{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Per {{commit|e8212743825365569b2162384eb653520b59c1d3}}, non-[[Knight]]s have a {{frac|30}} chance of transforming a long sword into [[Excalibur]] by dipping, making [[Snickersnee]] more of a priority in the early game unless they find an [[altar]] and a means of securing high [[luck]].}} ==== General ==== The samurai strategy is very simple: If it moves, stab it, and if it's [[sessile]], stab it anyway. Samurai are also good ranged warriors, receiving a bonus to hit and damage when shooting ya from a yumi. Samurai aren't good at [[spellcasting]], but are very unlikely to need it; the katana and splint mail they start with also make the first few levels a breeze. === Mid game === ==== Objectives ==== The Samurai quest item is the [[Tsurugi of Muramasa]], a powerful two-handed tsurugi with the ability to bisect enemies (i. e. kill them outright) 5% of the time, much like the [[Vorpal Blade]]. Therefore it is not a good idea to engage your quest nemesis in honourable melee combat, since he might bisect you; making things worse, he ignores [[Elbereth]]. It's better to zap him with a wand of death. If you don't have one, other techniques include zapping him with a wand of sleep or hurling a potion of paralysis at him before attacking so that he can't fight back, protecting yourself with a [[scroll of earth]] on the upstair and killing him with ranged attacks, [[polymorph]]ing into a [[black dragon]] and disintegrating him, and so forth. If you have a strong melee attack, you could just wear an [[amulet of life saving]] and hope for the best, possibly retreating if you have to burn the amulet; actually, having an [[amulet of life saving]] is probably a good idea anyway no matter what strategy you choose, just in case. The quest is notable for producing a lot of loot, especially attack wands, which your opponents will use against you. [[Reflection]], or at least resistance to sleep, fire, and cold, are highly desirable. ==== Weapons ==== With maxed strength and enchantment, shuriken and ya deal roughly comparable damage (since ya do not benefit from your [[strength|strength bonus]]). Ya are slightly more effective when you have a substantial [[ring of increase damage|damage bonus]], thanks to the Samurai's +1 multishot bonus when using them. Shuriken, on the other hand, do not require a wielded launcher (potentially saving valuable turns), and are generally more plentiful thanks to the [[Samurai quest|Quest]]. Since you take an [[alignment record]] penalty when using poisoned missiles, poisoning your entire stack is a [[Bad Idea]], but it might be worth poisoning a subset of your missiles to use against monsters such as [[minotaur]]s and [[mind flayer]]s, where killing them quickly is more important than a few points of alignment. The [[Tsurugi of Muramasa]] isn't as useful as it might seem, as it compares unfavorably to twoweaponing Excalibur and your starting katana, and doesn't provide any essential [[extrinsics]]. === Late game === ==== Weapons ==== Samurai typically get the most out of two-weaponing, using Excalibur with an offhand katana or silver saber through the endgame; [[Frost Brand]], [[Fire Brand]] or [[Grayswandir]] can replace Excalibur in the primary slot if you have them available, and can also be swapped into that slot against specific monsters. If no other source of reflection is available for you, you can forgo two-weapon fighting for a [[shield of reflection]]. ==== General ==== If you want to twoweapon in the late game and also wear an [[amulet of life saving]], you will probably want a [[cloak of magic resistance]] paired with [[silver dragon scale mail]], using a wish for the cloak if necessary. Relying on a quest artifact like the [[Magic Mirror of Merlin]] for magic resistance is risky, because the [[Wizard of Yendor]] can steal it, leaving you vulnerable to his [[touch of death]]. ==Rank titles== The [[status line]] shows you to be one of the following ranks when you reach the specified experience level: *XL 1-2: Hatamoto *XL 3-5: Ronin *XL 6-9: Ninja/Kunoichi *XL 10-13: Joshu *XL 14-17: Ryoshu *XL 18-21: Kokushu *XL 22-25: Daimyo *XL 26-29: Kuge *XL 30: Shogun == Quest == {{main|Samurai quest}} The Samurai quest sees you fight [[Ashikaga Takauji]] for the [[Tsurugi of Muramasa]]. ==Variants== ===Additional Japanese item names=== In several variants, including [[SlashTHEM]], and [[NetHack--]], these additional items have Japanese names: {| class="prettytable" !
